Master_Shake

Sorry, this is just one of those things that bugs me, so I thought I'd share it here.
 
 Techno is not music. Call me old-fashioned, but to me music requires the use of MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS. A computer is not a musical instrument, unless of course you beat it with sticks (something I would sometimes like to do to my computer :) emoticon_xkill ) then it might be able to qualify as a crude percussion instrument, but that is it.
 
 A cacophonous arrangment of sampled beeps and boops and drum machines and other sounds is not music, it's lazy.

I hate these posts. This same thing has been said about jazz, rock, rap, and even Chopin.

Master_Shake

I hate these posts. This same thing has been said about jazz, rock, rap, and even Chopin.
 
 Of course it is music. Personal opinion is not definition. 
 
 (For the record, I don't like it either. I also don't care for jazz.)

 You're right, a personal opinion alone isn't a definition, but that doesn't mean some definitions or qualifications can't exist, even minimal ones. Forgive me for having such a minimal qualification as using musical instruments. That just seems pretty basic to me. It's like saying that for something to be considered a painting, it has to use paint.
 
 It also doesn't really matter that the same thing has been said about actual music. That's irrelevant.
 
 I don't wholly dislike every bit of techno. I'm not saying it isn't music out of dislike. It just isn't music.
joebrummer

Sorry, this is just one of those things that bugs me, so I thought I'd share it here.
 
 Techno is not music. Call me old-fashioned, but to me music requires the use of MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS. A computer is not a musical instrument, unless of course you beat it with sticks (something I would sometimes like to do to my computer :) emoticon_xkill ) then it might be able to qualify as a crude percussion instrument, but that is it.
 
 A cacophonous arrangment of sampled beeps and boops and drum machines and other sounds is not music, it's lazy.

 
 Where do I start....
 
 I have been a classically trained piano player for most of my 35 years.... I have played in cover bands, folk duos and orginal bands where I was the main song writer.....
 
 Playing computer music...techno included takes a lot of skill, and patience. You need to fight a computer and still try to be creative at the same time. It also needed that you take sounds that may or may not be musical and make them musical. This takes a degree of talent and a whole different skill set as a musician.
 
 Years ago I was the House studio player at a recording studio and had to play whatever the client wanted....I played keys on rap, salsa, folk, singer song writer stuff and more.....I learned a bunch about computer music. I also learned how much talent it really takes to pull off a sax solo and make it sound good....I learned it can be done. 
 
 I love techno, if it is good stuff!
 
 I would direct you to my website, go to the music page and listen to "heaven help me" there is a really nice sax solo most people think is a sax....it isn't...it is a computer.....
 
 Just my thought, but just like other things in life....it takes talent to be good at anything, and computer music is the same....it takes training, knowledge of the instrument and creativity to pull it off. You may not like it or appreciate it, but if you listen anything from moby, understand that was not the computer making music....someone had to program the computer to make it do that....Computers are only as creative as the person sitting in front of the screen as you can see from these forums!
Ooaman

If it's not noise but has a rythem, then it's sound or music. That's a definition. If it's generated, it's not true music.
 
Techno is not music. Call me old-fashioned, but to me music requires the use of MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS. A computer is not a musical instrument...

 But it does have a keyboard. And so far, that keyboard is the only instrument I can play other than air guitar. Oh, and I can also play the CD Player. emoticon_xclown

 Well, first of all let me say that I don't think that most of the techno out there is skillful. I say this because I have heard more than several people's share of it. I know it isn't necessarily all that difficult because I have friends that do it and these people aren't what you would call the brightest crayon in the box.
 
 At any rate, what I really want to say here is just because something takes skill or talent and doesn't make it music. Being a million-words-a-minute auctioneer takes skill and talent and requires sound too, but that doesn't make it music.

 I disagree, I have heard some really great techno I thought was awesome stuff. I am a big Moby fan. I think he does some great stuff, I also love the band "everything but the girl", who do a mix of techno and other. 
 
 On the other hand I have heard some crappy techno. But as someone who has done some techno stuff (being a keys player) It wasn't easy. My few attempts at it were lame. You really need to build the song to make it interesting, but never loose the beat (or people can't dance) It is all about dancing with techno and it is difficult to keep it interesting, have a nice flow without being boring and still keeping the pace so people can dance without interupting the flow. I think like rap and some other forms of music. What is amazing music to one is noise to others.
 
 The lastest techno mixes for Sarah Mclachlan were awful, the beat doesn't match the vocal and the sounds chosen seem too overdone. I think if people are going to make techno then like anything else. Some will be great and some will....**uck

You're right, a personal opinion alone isn't a definition, but that doesn't mean some definitions or qualifications can't exist, even minimal ones. Forgive me for having such a minimal qualification as using musical instruments. That just seems pretty basic to me. It's like saying that for something to be considered a painting, it has to use paint.

 I don't wholly dislike every bit of techno. I'm not saying it isn't music out of dislike. It just isn't music.

 
 Most music now has an electronic element to it. Is an electric guitar music? A keyboard (not a computer keyboard, like a piano)? What about recording 2 tracks of music and combining them? People have done duets in different countries thanks to electronics. I'm not sure about your definition of techno is, but now a lot of music played from a computer can sound almost identical to the regular instrument.

Music is the arrangement of sounds in time to produce a composition. Techno songs tend to meet that requirement. A musical instrument is a device that makes music. If a computer makes music, whether you beat it with a stick, or make a techno song, then it is a musical instrument.

You know, there are some artists/bands who are "perfectionist" who absolutely will not play certain instruments. For example, the band Boston (my all time favorite band) refuses to play any keyboards with synthesizers. Also, there are drummers who refuse to bang sticks on flat pannels that are set up like drums to produce the sound of drums. There are some people that insist on playing acoustic guitars as opposed to electric guitars. I know that this thread started off about Techno "Music" but it seems to have gone off on to a tangent of what music is.
 My personal opinion right now is that it has to have a drum beat (or some beat for tapping your feet/toes to.) emoticon_cool

Music is the voice of the only true universal language - mathematics.
DubyRunning

Techno is not music. Call me old-fashioned, but to me music requires the use of MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS.

 
 Call me a contemporary, but techno is in fact music. Also, music does not require the implementation of actual physical musical instruments, but is rather (as according to Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, 10th Edition): 
 
 "the science or art of ordering tones or sounds in succession, in combination, and in temporal relationships to produce a composition having unity and continuity."
 
 Not only is Master Shake's assertion that techno isn't music, which clearly deviates from its most widely-understood definition, whether it's correct or not, based entirely in opinion, he also never defines what music actually is. So, with a feasible definition at hand, it's clear that techno fits its parameters rather well.
 
 Also, on a less essential note: Shake, you said that you don't "wholly dislike" every bit of techno. That said, what exactly do you like about it, given that it is not in fact music?
billsco

I program a synthesizer for my musical projects. I've noticed that when the drums and bass tracks are laid down, a certain sterility in the music is encountered. If I open up the program and begin manipulating the notes--nudging one here and there a shade off top dead center--a human quality begins to be felt in the music. The slight imperfections add warmth.
 
 This may be what some people don't like about techno, its mechanical feel.
Master_Shake

Shake, you said that you don't "wholly dislike" every bit of techno. That said, what exactly do you like about it, given that it is not in fact music?

 I have to consider it music to like some of it on some level? That's an absurd suggestion. But to answer your question, I said I don't wholly dislike it, not that I like it. There is a difference. If I said something "wasn't bad" that doesn't exactly mean I thought it was good. But anyway, some of it can be fine as wallpaper sometimes, but that's about it.

Ecstacy:
 As if convincing countless innocents to spend nights crushed into dilapidated warehouses, waving glowsticks and bouncing along to the same monotonous groove wasn't bad enough, ecstasy also taught a generation of dance-music auteurs that songwriting was as easy as looping a beat, then taking a nap.

Master_Shake, when you say techno, are you falling into the common trap of labeling all electronica music "techno", or are you actually referring to the actual sub-genre of techno?

 It seems in all of music there's a sub-genre for every band, or artist, or DJ, or whatever. That's gotten out of hand, but that's a subject for another thread altogether :). That being said, I haven't spent enough time rollin to learn all of the sub-genres, so I suppose where I say "techno", you can replace it with "electronica."*** Although historically speaking, and you can correct me if I'm wrong here, techno is an older term than electronica.
 
 ***There may be an exception for electronica where vocals play a major role, such as NIN.

 Maybe their name popped up here because a lot of fans of electronic or techno styles of music also like Industrial - which is not the same thing - but more of an aoffshoot of heavy metal.

 Look, as you probably picked up on, I don't care much for putting everything into sub-genres, but, just from listening, the sound of much of NIN is electronic to me. When I made that comment, I was only saying it based on my own listening, not because I'm a fan of industrial (because I'm not). You can tell me if I'm totally off base here, but it seems pretty evident that there are plenty of electronic sounds in NIN. In addition, it seems to me that when the sounds do come from an instrument, most of the time they have been heavily manipulated electronically.

jim's trucking

Let me interject the thoughts of this lover of music.
 
 Music is defined in Webster's as:
 
 the science or art of ordering tones or sounds in succession, in combination, and in temporal relationships to produce a composition having unity and continuity
 
 vocal, instrumental, or mechanical sounds having rhythm, melody OR harmony
 
 an agreeable sound
 
 musical: having the pleasing harmonious qualities of music
 
 Now...for a word from our poster:
 
 There are multitudes of forms of music as defined above. No matter the source of the sounds, a work that exhibits pleasing rhythmic, melodious OR harmonizing sounds can fall under this definition, be it produced by wind, string, brass, percussion, computer, screech owls, whales, nailguns, foot stompers, spoons, a comb and paper, a stretched balloon neck, pots and pans, a scrub board and fingernails, drum beaters, tap shoes, etc ad infinitum<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<.
 
 If the composer of a completely computer generated sound has knowledge of music and produces sounds that are pleasing in rhythm, melody OR harmony, then he/she has produced music. While it is far beneath the true value of what has been traditionally labeled as music, it is nonetheless---music.
 
 Of all the various forms of sounds I've heard labeled as music, the main one that stands out as a farce is RAP! RAP is nothing more than jive-XXX poetry shouted over a rhythmic sound produced by someone who does actually know a little about music. The rapper himself is as close to a talentless waste as I can think of. That they have a following at all amazes me daily. That they have yet failed in killing each other off is disturbing. Monotone shouting of poems by thugs and disrespectors does not make music to my ears.
